title: What's correct 'a university' or 'an university'? What about other words with the first letter 'u'? - Quora

response.answer_text: “A university” is correct. The spelling of a word doesn’t always correspond closely to the word’s phonetics. We sometimes say that the letters aeiou (and sometimes y) are vowels. This is not quite true: these letters often (but now always) represent vowels. Vowels and consonants are “sounds,” not letters, and sometimes there is a mismatch between the The thing is, the a/an distinction applies to the phonetics of the word, and has nothing to do with its spelling. The word university does not actually begin with a vowel: it begins with the consonant /j/ (that’s how the “y” sound is written in phonetic notation). We say “an honorable man” because honorable actually begins with a vowel. The h is just a letter in how the word is spelled, but is not part of the word’s phonetics at all. Acronyms are another example of how the word’s phonetics differ from how it is spelled. We talk about “an MRI” because MRI begins with the vowel /ɛ/. (I put “sounds” in quotation marks in the second paragraph because the proper term here would be phoneme. If you do not know what a phoneme is and would like to, I encourage you to read more!)

A University is correct. The general rule is that a is used when the u at the start of the following word is pronounced as y. Unicorn is pronounced yewnicorn so it's a unicorn. The same goes for unique, useful. Upset is pronounced with a short u so it's an upset. The same goes for udder, ultra, umbrella.
